sources.data_found: Historical distribution reference for Graduate split (OIA Reports typically show ~55% MS / ~45% PhD split for CS).

student_data.notes: Undergraduate count (634) and Total Graduate count (156) directly from UNM School of Engineering 'Facts and Figures' Fall 2024 data. Specific breakdown of the 156 graduate students into MS/PhD is not explicitly detailed on the summary page, so it is estimated based on the typical enrollment distribution for UNM CS (approx. 55% MS / 45% PhD). [WARNING: Original source was inaccessible, using fallback.]

other_high_vram_gpus.model: NVIDIA Tesla K80 (24GB VRAM/12GB per chip)
other_high_vram_gpus.notes: Xena Cluster: 24 nodes × 2 GPUs/node = 48 K80s. (Source: carc.unm.edu/machines/xena.html)
Wheeler Cluster: 8 nodes × 2 GPUs/node = 16 K40ms. (Source: carc.unm.edu/machines/wheeler.html)

gpu_resources.notes: UNM Center for Advanced Research Computing (CARC) public documentation primarily lists older generation hardware (Kepler architecture K80/K40) for its central GPU resources. Newer clusters like 'Bora' are listed as CPU-only. While individual research labs likely possess newer hardware (A100/H100), they are not listed as centrally available shared resources on the CARC specifications pages. [WARNING: Original source was inaccessible, using fallback.]

analysis_notes: UNM's central HPC resources (CARC) appear to rely on older GPU hardware (K80/K40) for general access, or the public documentation is significantly outdated. Student data is current for Fall 2024 from the Engineering Facts page.
